Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10). The exact wording states: "Nothing in the foregoing provisions of this Part shall derogate from the power of Parliament to make any provision with respect to the acquisition and termination of citizenship and all other matters relating to citizenship." This provision explicitly grants Parliament the authority to enact laws that may modify or supersede the citizenship provisions outlined in Articles 5 to 10.

Reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right conferred by Article 19(1)(a) can be imposed by the State in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation or incitement to an offence.
